g.text: Evolution of the Structural, Mechanical, and Phonon
Properties of GeSe Polymorphs in a Pressure-Induced
School of Physics and Electronic Engineering, Leshan Normal University, Leshan 614004, China;
State Key Laboratory of Electrical Insulation and Power Equipment & School of Electrical Engineering,

Received: 3 September 2019; Accepted: 31 October 2019; Published: 3 November 2019
A pressure-induced structural transition from the layered-like phase (
) in GeSe was investigated with ﬁrst principle calculations. The variations of
the structural, electronic, elastic, and vibrational properties of GeSe with the application of pressure
were obtained. The transformation from the
phase structure showed dynamical stability above 37 GPa. The lattice parameters and the equation
of state varied continuously at the transition pressure. Obvious sti
constants associated with the compressive and shear components was observed to occur within the
phase transition process. Two characteristic Raman modes (A
signiﬁcant softening by increasing the pressure.
phase transition; ﬁrst principle calculations; elastic constant; phonon mode softening
GeSe, a typical bilayer IV-VI compound, has attracted much attention with respect to
its low thermal conductivity, excellent electrical and optical properties, as well as excellent thermal
stability and low-toxic constituent elements. At atmospheric pressure, GeSe crystallizes into an
space group. The unit cell contains eight atoms, arranged in two
layers, and each layer consists of four atoms; all of themare located at the 4c Wycko
a. The atoms within the layer form strong covalent Ge–Se bonds, and
each Ge atomis coordinated with the other three nearest Se atoms. Additionally, the interlayer is piled
up with weak van der Waals interaction along the a axis, and it forms a zigzag Ge–Se chain along the
ort has been put into understanding the structural phase transition mechanism
]. In one of the earliest studies, Bhatia et al. [
observed a phase transition of GeSe froma non-metallic orthorhombic structure to a metallic rock salt
structure at 6 GPa. Hsueh et al. [
] reported that they could not locate the structural phase transition
up to 13 GPa, but the predicted electronic structure transformation froma non-metallic into metallic
state was about 6 GPa. In addition, Onodera et al. [
] also argued that GeSe could retain orthorhombic
symmetry up to 82 GPa, but it showed metallic behavior above 25 GPa. Recently, Xu et al. used XRDto
